noun.description: The short, thick first digit of the human hand, set lower and apart from the other four and opposable to them.

verb.description: Press, move, or touch (something) with one's thumb.
examples: as soon as she thumbed the button, the door slid open

phrases: I'm all thumbs when it comes to making bows
His bumbling, childlike Mr Bean was all thumbs and two left feet, and the fact that he rarely spoke meant his vaudevillian humour travelled well.
I am not just all thumbs, more all toes.
I'm trying to get a PDF of the letter up as well, but I'm all thumbs with this pesky technology, so bear with me.
I've been all thumbs and screw up everything I touch.
origin: Old English thūma, of West Germanic origin; related to Dutch duim and German Daumen, from an Indo-European root shared by Latin tumere to swell. The verb dates from the late 16th century, first in the sense play (a musical instrument) with the thumbs.
